title: Debtor did a fraudulent conveyance with zero value 2 weeks before he filed chapter 7. How do I get standing?
question: I am the only judgment creditor. Trustee did not want to pursue with debtor's fraudulent conveyance.
answers:
Generally speaking, the issue is not whether you have standing as a judgment creditor per se. Creditors do have standing to bring such suits under state law (Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act or Uniform Fraudulent Conveyance Act, depending on the state). However, if the debtor obtains a discharge, you will not be a creditor any longer because your claim will have been forgiven. That is why several attorneys asked about when the case was filed and whether the deadline for objecting to discharge under section 727 has passed.

Also, sometimes a court will allow a creditor to pursue a claim in the name of the trustee if the trustee is unwilling to do so and there is a viable claim. To pursue that route (and any other) you should consult a local attorney.

Your inquiry also indicates, however, that you have a judgment against the debtor. Did you obtain a judgment lien ? Have you spoken to the attorney who represented you in obtaining the judgment about further enforcement efforts ?

The trustee has 2 years from the petition date to bring the fraudulent conveyance claim and sometimes they will not pursue a claim because there is no money in the estate and they are unable to retain contingency fee counsel. Have you offered to pay an attorney to represent the trustee to bring the claim ? You might want to consult a local attorney about that as well.

Creditors do not have standing to undo or pursue fraudulent conveyances.

Generally, as brother counsel has stated, you would raise this in an objection to discharge. The objection would point out that there is a lack of good faith in the debtor's filing due to failure to disclose the conveyance - as Form 107 asks about transfers outside the ordinary course of business that occurred two years prior to filing.

However there is a deadline to object to discharge and, unless the deadline was extended by motion or stipulation, you may be, as they say, S.O.L.

If you really feel strongly, I suppose you could write the US trustee for your region.

Warm regards,

Al

Did you find out about the bankruptcy in the normal way, within a week or so after it was filed?

What date was the initial date set for the Meeting of Creditors?

The deadline for you to file an adversary proceeding objecting to the discharge as to your debt, or as to the discharge in general, is 60 days from the date initially set for the Meeting of Creditors.
You should have hired an attorney and filed an objection to discharge, but you only had sixty days from the creditor meeting to do it.
The answers above are well-reasoned. You should seek local counsel!
